awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Promoting a Growth Mindset Using Automated Feedback
awd_abstract_narration:
The "Promoting a Growth Mindset Using Automated Feedback" project will develop and evaluate a new strategy for generating automated feedback on programming assignments that will provide a more welcoming experience for students, recognizing the effort they put in as they work on solutions.  The goal of the project will be to promote the adoption of a "growth mindset" - a belief that one's abilities will improve with practice and hard work, which is associated with a range of improved educational outcomes.  This strategy will encompass four key ideas: a measurement approach for assessing student effort; the use of non-points-based bonuses to reward effort and recognize hard work for positive reinforcement; heat maps of student code to highlight where bugs are located; and a strategy for clearly identifying the top priority for students to tackle in order to make progress. 

During the first year of the project, all three schools will collect baseline data using existing "conventional" feedback approaches. The new feedback intervention will be evaluated in years two and three of the project.  Quantitative and qualitative data will be collected and analyzed to examine changes in performance and students' behavior.  A mixed-method data collection plan will triangulate the quantitative and qualitative data with the review of literature and the researchers' direct experience in teaching these courses to reach conclusions regarding research questions of the study and provide the framework for the design of a scalable and replicable intervention to improve students' performance in the programming projects.

por.por_cntn:
The work performed at UNC at Charlotte for this award involved the adoption and evaluation of the impact on students for new approaches to automated feedback that promotes a growth mindset. The development of these techniques were done and assessed at Virginia Tech. At UNCC we wanted to assess the impact that these techniques had in our diverse student body. We have one of the most diverse student undergraduate bodies in computing. Unfortunately, data collection at UNCC was interrupted by the impact of the pandemic and the move to online education.

Curiously, as faculty searched for how to support students at this difficult time, automated graders became more accepted as pedagogical tools. After a couple of years of promoting and encouraging use of automated graders, the onset of the pandemic prompted many to revisit their objections and adopt Web-CAT and other automated tools. Officially, UNCC has adopted several automated tools for ALL of our intro courses. The faculty and institutional desire to provide additional support for our students outweigh preconceived notions of what automated grading could do. Upon returning to face-to-face (Fall 2021), our intro courses retained the use of automated graders, including Web-CAT, CodeWorkout, CSAwesome (Runestone course), and even exploring locally developed adaptive options within Canvas.

Unfortunately, students were reluctant to participate in human-subject projects, even when when participation was completely online. We had very few students sign the consent forms. The pandemic had a significant impact in our students, many of them with financial needs. This prevented us from completing data collection in a way that would contribute to the assessment of the techniques developed at Virginia Tech.
